Award.AwardTitle: EAGER SitS:Collaborative Research:Projecting Arctic soil and ecosystem responses to warming using SCAMPS: A stoichiometrically coupled, acclimating microbe-plant-soil model
Award.AbstractNarration: Understanding future arctic terrestrial carbon balance is vital because high latitude soils contain about twice as much carbon as is in the atmosphere and its release would drive a major acceleration of atmospheric carbon dioxide accumulation. This research will advance the understanding of processes regulating the storage and release of carbon from arctic soils across biological and physical scales using a modeling approach. The study will promote both basic research into the controls on arctic soil and ecosystem processes and be applicable to management agencies by describing how linked biotic-abiotic responses to unprecedented warming may influence future carbon balance in Arctic terrestrial ecosystems. Further, this grant will help advance the career of an Assistant Professor at a primarily undergraduate institution, while enhancing gender and racial diversity in the biogeosciences. This research will also directly enhance undergraduate education in arctic biogeoscience through directed mentorship of undergraduate researchers; the research approach and findings will also be incorporated into courses and other teaching activities by the primary investigators.<br/><br/>Field studies suggest that inconsistent responses to comparable experimental manipulations across arctic tundra ecosystems might be driven by local variation in the plant and decomposer community. However, the relative importance of, and links between, key biotic (e.g. microbial acclimation) and abiotic factors (e.g. altered snowpack, thaw depth, and nutrient availability) that govern these divergent responses of tundra to climate variation, remains unknown. This project will synthesize available data from ambient and experimental manipulations of arctic ecosystems. The investigators will then use the synthesis to refine, parameterize, and validate a changed version of the Stoichiometrically Coupled, Acclimating Microbe-Plant-Soil (SCAMPS) model. Simulations will explore how variation in seasonal warming and the acclimation potential of the soil microbial and plant community, encompassing community shifts, evolutionary adaptation, and physiological changes across tundra landscapes, affects biogeochemical feedbacks and regulates future carbon balance of arctic soils and ecosystems.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research sought to advance understanding of the processes regulating the sequestration and release of carbon from arctic soils across scales ranging from microbial physiology to ecosystem-level processes. Embedded within the context of training a postdoctoral scholar and undergraduate students, our project had two major goals: 1) to synthesize available data from ambient and experimental manipulations of arctic ecosystems in a comprehensive literature review/meta-analysis and use the synthesis to refine, parameterize, and validate a modified version of the Stoichiometrically Coupled, Acclimating Microbe-Plant-Soil (SCAMPS) model; and 2) Develop and use the modified SCAMPS model to explore how variation in seasonal warming and the acclimation potential of the soil microbial and plant community—encompassing community shifts, evolutionary adaptation, and physiological changes of the soil and plant communities across tundra landscapes— affects biogeochemical feedbacks and carbon balance of arctic soils and ecosystems.

We completed a meta-analysis of 166 experimental warming study papers to evaluate the hypotheses that warming changes tundra biogeochemical cycles in a habitat- and seasonally-specific manner, and that the carbon (C), nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) cycles will be differentially accelerated, leading to decoupling of elemental cycles. Led by a postdoctoral scholar and two undergraduate students, we found that nutrient availability and plant leaf stoichiometry responses to experimental warming were variable and overall weak, but that both gross primary productivity and the plant C pool tended to increase with growing season warming. The effects of winter warming on C fluxes did not extend into the growing season. Overall, although warming led to more consistent increases in C fluxes compared to N or P fluxes, evidence for decoupling of biogeochemical cycles is weak and any effect appears limited to heath habitats.  However, many arctic habitats have data that is too sparse to be able to generalize how climate warming (and its seasonal variability) might decouple biogeochemical cycles (Pold, G., N. Baillargeon, A. Lepe, E. B. Rastetter, and S. A. Sistla. 2021. Warming effects on arctic tundra biogeochemistry are limited but habitat-dependent: a meta-analysis. Ecosphere 12(10):e03777. 10.1002/ecs2.3777).

A separate analysis of the effects of over two decades of experimental summer warming on tussock tundra active and total bacterial communities using an older data set from PI Sistla resulted in a second publication (Pold, G, J.P. Schimel, S. S.Sistla. 2021. Soil bacterial communities vary more by season than with over two decades of experimental summer greenhouse warming in Arctic tussock tundra. Elementa: Science of the Anthropocene 9 (1): 00116). We found that changes in total and actively growing bacterial community structures were correlated with edaphic factors and time point sampled but were unaffected by warming. The aboveground plant community had become more shrub-dominated with warming at this site, suggesting that soil bacterial communities did not track changes in the aboveground plant community.

These efforts were used to inform the development and parameterization of the SCAMPS-CNP model. We compared how SCAMPS-CNP and the modified SCAMPS-CN models project how a moderate (RCP 6.0) air warming scenario will impact tussock tundra nutrient availability and ecosystem C stocks. SCAMPS-CNP was characterized by larger soil organic matter and smaller organism C stocks compared to SCAMPS-CN, and a greater reduction in ecosystem C stocks under warming. This difference can largely be attributed to a smaller microbial biomass in the CNP model, which, instead of being driven by direct costs of P acquisition, was driven by variable resource limitation due to asynchronous C, N, and P availability and demand. Our project demonstrates that seasonality and asynchrony in resource availability affect predicted ecosystem C storage dynamics under warming, and therefore supports the notion that stoichiometry should be explicitly considered in C cycling modeling efforts. This component of the project was published in: Pold, G., E. B. Rastetter, S. Sistla. Sporadic P limitation constrains microbial growth and facilitates SOM accumulation in the stoichiometrically coupled, acclimating microbe–plant–soil model. Soil Biology and Biochemistry 165 (108489) and presented as part of the Nutrient Cycling in Earth System Models - INCyTE 2021 Seminar Series.
